prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We propose to map CO(1-0) to a level of 2 mJy/beam at the highest resolution. The goal is to model the velocity field of the gas down to the sizes of individual GMCs. CO(1-0) is used because it is the best and brightest tracer of the overall molecular gas component. The maximum resolution of 0.36" is requested to map the velocity field down to the granularity of individual GMCs. We aim for a sensitivity of ~1-1.5 K, which we can attain with some velocity and spatial smothing. Nuclear structures tend to be brighter, which is why we request full spatial resolution. The full linewidth is wide, but we require 2-5 km/s resolution in each pixel to model the velocity field.

The maximum resolution of 0.36" is requested to map the velocity field down to the granularity of individual GMCs. We aim for a sensitivity of ~1-1.5 K, which we can attain with some velocity and spatial smothing. Nuclear structures tend to be brighter, which is why we request full spatial resolution. The full linewidth is wide, but we require 2-5 km/s velocity resolution in each pixel to do modeling of the velocity field.

We propose to map CO(1-0) to a level of 2 mJy/beam at the highest resolution. The goal is to model the velocity field of the gas down to the sizes of individual GMCs. CO(1-0) is used because it is the best and brightest tracer of the overall molecular gas component. The maximum resolution of 0.36" is requested to map the velocity field down to the granularity of individual GMCs. We aim for a sensitivity of ~1-1.5 K, which we can attain with some velocity and spatial smoothing. Nuclear structures tend to be brighter, which is why we request full spatial resolution. The full linewidth is large, but we require ~2-5km/s resolution in any given pixel, since we will be doing a model of the velocity field.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
There is substantial evidence that within the center of every galaxy lies a supermassive black hole. Albeit only a small fraction of the mass and size of their host galaxies, these objects are capable of changing the entire evolutionary path of their host galaxies through a process called ``AGN feedback.'' However, the exact manner in which AGN are fueled is still uncertain. A proposed mechanism that may fuel AGN is the ``bars within bars'' scenario; this mechanism is marked by the presence of a nuclear gaseous bar within a large-scale stellar bar.
Thus we propose to test this scenario by observing CO ($J$=1-0) in Band 3 for a sample of four barred AGN and four barred non-AGN galaxies. {\it We expect to observe nuclear gaseous bars in barred AGN galaxies, while we do not expect to see this feature in barred non-AGN galaxies.} The excellent resolution of ALMA will spatially resolve structures down to tens of parsecs, which is adequate for resolving nuclear gaseous bars. Moreover, we will use the kinematical information to model these galaxies, yielding detailed information of the gas flows around the supermassive black holes.
